title: The Returned Exiles and Temple Service
shortSummary: 1 Chronicles 9 details the genealogies and the organization of the returned exiles in Jerusalem after the Babylonian captivity. It highlights the families of the Israelites, priests, Levites, and gatekeepers, emphasizing their roles in the service and upkeep of the temple, underscoring the importance of order and faithfulness in worship.
timeline: c. 538 BC - Post-exilic period following the return from Babylonian captivity

keyCharacters.name: Jedaiah
keyCharacters.description: A priest mentioned as one of the heads of the priestly families responsible for temple service.

keyCharacters.name: Shallum
keyCharacters.description: Chief porter and gatekeeper at the king's gate, responsible for overseeing the temple gates and their security.

keyCharacters.name: Phinehas
keyCharacters.description: Son of Eleazar, formerly a ruler over the gatekeepers and noted for the LORD’s presence with him.

keyCharacters.name: Mattithiah
keyCharacters.description: A Levite and firstborn of Shallum the Korahite, charged with overseeing temple utensils.

definitions.definition: Temple servants or dedicated workers assigned to assist the Levites in their duties.
Gatekeepers responsible for guarding the entrances to the temple and managing access.
The bread of the Presence, twelve loaves placed on a special table in the sanctuary as an offering to God.
A clan of Levites descended from Korah, often assigned specific temple duties such as gatekeeping and music.

outline.heading: Genealogical Record of the Returned Exiles
outline.description: This section lists the families of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh who resettled in Jerusalem, emphasizing the continuity of God's people despite exile.

outline.heading: Priests and Levites Assigned to Temple Service
outline.description: Details the names and roles of priests and Levites, including gatekeepers, highlighting the organized structure for temple worship and the importance of faithful service.

outline.heading: Duties and Responsibilities of Temple Servants
outline.description: Describes the specific tasks of the Levites and priests, such as guarding gates, managing temple vessels, preparing shewbread, and making ointments, illustrating the sacred nature of their work.

outline.heading: Genealogy of the Gibeonites and Descendants of Saul
outline.description: Records the lineage of the Gibeonites and the family of Saul, connecting the historical and spiritual heritage of Israel’s leaders.

application: Commit to faithful service in the church, recognizing that every role, like those of the Levites and gatekeepers, is vital to God's work.
Value the importance of order and accountability in worship and ministry, following the example of the organized temple service.
Remember God's faithfulness in preserving His people through trials and exile, encouraging perseverance in times of hardship.
Cultivate a heart of stewardship over spiritual responsibilities, just as the priests and Levites carefully managed the temple's sacred duties.

keyVerses.text: So they and their children had the oversight of the gates of the house of the LORD, namely, the house of the tabernacle, by wards.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the generational faithfulness and responsibility entrusted to God's servants in protecting His sanctuary.

keyVerses.text: And Phinehas the son of Eleazar was the ruler over them in time past, and the LORD was with him.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes God's presence with faithful leaders who serve Him diligently.

keyVerses.text: And they lodged round about the house of God, because the charge was upon them, and the opening thereof every morning pertained to them.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates the dedication and vigilance required in serving the Lord continually.
